Amazon's Algo World

Advanced Data Structures and Optimization Strategies

Amazon Company Overview

AWS Market Share

Amazon.com, Inc. is an American multinational technology company focusing on e-commerce, cloud computing, online advertising, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence. Founded by Jeff Bezos in 1994, Amazon has grown from an online bookstore to one of the world's most valuable companies.

Amazon Headquarters in Seattle, Washington

Amazon's Product Ecosystem

Amazon operates across multiple business segments, each leveraging sophisticated algorithms and data structures to deliver optimal user experiences:

E-commerce Platform
Amazon Web Services
Prime Video
Alexa & Echo

Business Cases

The following business cases demonstrate how specific algorithms and data structures optimize Amazon's core operations:

1
Real-Time Dynamic Pricing
Adjusting product prices on the fly based on fluctuating user demand and market trends using segment trees for efficient range updates.
Algorithm: Segment Trees
2
Autocomplete Search Bar using Trie + BFS
Implementing a real-time search suggestion system using a Trie data structure with Best-First Search to return top query completions based on frequency.
Algorithm: Trie + BFS (Priority Queue)
3
Urban Delivery Clusters
Optimize Amazon truck routes by identifying the largest connected high-demand delivery zones within urban grids using DFS/BFS on a matrix.
Algorithm: Grid Island Detection (DFS/BFS on Matrix)
4
Inventory Optimization with Knapsack Problem
Select products to restock within limited warehouse space to maximize profit by solving the classic 0/1 Knapsack optimization challenge.
Algorithm: 0/1 Knapsack Dynamic Programming
5
Fraud Detection Using Substring Algorithms
Identify suspicious transaction patterns in real-time by matching user activity with known fraud signatures using efficient string matching techniques.
Algorithm: Knuth–Morris–Pratt_algorithm
6
Job Assignment Problem for Warehouse Optimization
Optimize the assignment of warehouses to delivery regions to minimize total transportation cost and improve delivery efficiency using advanced dynamic programming techniques.
Algorithm: Bitmask Dynamic Programming
7
Amazon Prime Video - Fuzzy Search
Matching user queries with movie and TV titles using fuzzy matching techniques to tolerate typos, incomplete input, or word order differences, improving search accuracy and user experience.
Algorithm: Longest Common Subsequence (LCS)
8
Product-Promotion Matching
Matching products with the most relevant promotional campaigns based on mutual preferences using the Stable Marriage Algorithm.
Algorithm: Stable Marriage Algorithm (Gale-Shapley)
9
Coupon Combination Problem
Calculating the number of ways customers can combine different discount coupons to achieve exact discount amounts using dynamic programming.
Algorithm: Coin Change (Dynamic Programming)
10
Efficient Querying in Big Datasets Using Sparse Table
Efficiently answering queries like "What was the minimum price between day X and Y?" using sparse table preprocessing in Amazon's historical pricing analytics.
Algorithm: Sparse Table (Range Minimum Query)
11
Maximum Flow Computation Using Ford-Fulkerson
Computing the maximum possible flow in a supply chain network, optimizing the throughput from source to sink nodes using the Ford-Fulkerson method.
Algorithm: Ford-Fulkerson (Max Flow)
12
Optimizing Prime Video Streaming with Floyd-Warshall Algorithm
Finding shortest paths between all pairs of nodes in a network to optimize data routing and reduce latency.
Algorithm: Floyd-Warshall
13
Optimize Delivery Routes: A* Search and Uniform Cost Search in Amazon Logistics
Using A* Search and Uniform Cost Search algorithms to compute the most efficient and cost-effective delivery paths across Amazon's global network of fulfillment centers and last-mile delivery hubs.
Algorithm: A* Search, Uniform Cost Search
